item.title: MachineLearningPartIII
item.description: K-means Illustration of the algorithm $$ \begin{split} &\text{Step1: Randomly initialize K centroids, }\mu_1,\mu_2,…,\mu_k\\space\ &\text{Step2: Assign points to closest centroids, }c^{(i)}.\\space\ &\text{Step3: Recompute the locations of centroids}\ &\quad\quad\quad\text{by calculating the average of the points assigned to them.}\\space\ &\text{step4: repeat Step2 and Step3, until there is no further change.} \end{split} $$ NOTICE In step1, the most commonly used way is to randomly choose K training examples(points) and set them as the centroids.

item.description: Pseudocode operators choice: IF and CASE loop data type declaration records array 1D array 2D array files constant procedure function Flowchart example: Key concepts Abstract data type

item.title: CS Review U1[Finetuned]
item.description: Chapter 1 Show understanding of binary magnitudes and the difference between binary prefixes and decimal prefixes Show understanding of the basis of different number systems Use the binary, denary, hexadecimal number bases and Binary Coded Decimal (BCD) and one’s and two’s complement representation for binary numbers Convert an integer value from one number base / representation to another Two’s complement – each binary digit is reversed and 1 is added in right-most position to produce another method of representing positive and negative numbers.

item.title: Notes on machine learning 2
item.description: Diagram of a neural network model Implement a neural network Libraries: import tensorflow as tf from tensorflow.keras.models import Sequential from tensorflow.keras.layers import Dense from tensorflow.keras.activations import relu, linear, sigmoid, softmax from tensorflow.keras.losses import SparseCategoricalCrossentropy, BinaryCrossentropy from tensorflow.keras.optimizers import Adam Create a layer TensorFlow: Dense(units=, activation='') DIY: def my_dense_layer(a_in, W, b, g): ''' a_in: input W: parameters b: parameters g: activation function ''' units = W.shape[1] # number of neurons in this layer a_out = np.

item.title: Notes on machine learning 1
item.description: Notice: the note only contains the part 1 of the specialization. Regression Model $f(\overrightarrow x)=\overrightarrow w\cdot\overrightarrow x+b=w_1x_1+w_2x_2+…+w_nx_n+b$ Terminology $\overrightarrow x$: features.(It can be scalar if there is only one feature) $y$: the output.(given by dataset) $m$: the number of trianing examples. n: the number of features. $x^{(i)}, y^{(i)}$: the $i$th trianing example. $f(x), \hat y$: the estimated value of y. $\overrightarrow w, b$: parameters of the model. Cost function $J(\overrightarrow w, b) = {1\over2m}\sum_{i=1}^m(f(x^{(i)}) - y^{(i)})^2$

item.title: Build your blog by Hugo + Github Pages
item.description: 0 Foreword This is my first blog and I want to record the process I build this blog site on Windows. 1 Prerequisites First, you need to download/install the following: Go Git Hugo Please add them to environment variables. You can check using the following commands: go version git version hugo version 2 Build your site 2.1 generate folder Run the following command: hugo new site my_blog It would generate a folder named my_blog in current directory and the following are the functions of these files/folders:
